abstract.p: Previous research indicates mixed conclusions on the potential mispricing of equity index put options. We examine the returns of put writing and other option strategies by comparing historical option returns with returns generated using option pricing models. We find it is generally possible to reject the hypothesis that put returns are consistent with option pricing models. An implication is that the average cost of buying out-of-the-money put options to provide tail-risk protection to a portfolio may include a significant premium. Our results are based on a sample period of 1987–2012 that includes periods of high volatility in equity returns.

p.mixed-citation: Gabaix (2012) suggests a list of important finance puzzles that includes put pricing. Jackwerth and Rubinstein (1996) provide an analysis of option mispricing, and Broadie, Chernov, and Johannes (2009) review literature regarding option mispricing.
For the sake of brevity, most of the details of the methodology employed by BCJ are not repeated here but are available in Broadie, Chernov, and Johannes (2009).
We thank an anonymous referee for providing this simplified approach.
The unconditional spot variance has a gamma distribution as demonstrated by Cox, Ingersoll, and Ross (1985).
